reviewText:
Good stuff
- Low-gravity powers are cool since they involve throwing objects, grabbing people from far away and smashing them into walls, etc.
- Enemies get messed up nicely. Decapitations, limbs getting severed, bodies just exploding into nothingness, etc.
- Some neat locales and cool set-pieces
- Serviceable story. There were probably plenty of holes but as an excuse for an action game, it ain't bad.

Bad stuff
- High-gravity powers are bland. One of them stops enemies from moving. Why stop when you can kill? The other creates a shield. That's nice I suppose but as soon as you get the shield enemies start doing more damage, so you're kinda forced into using it.
- Bosses get re-used so much. It's not noticeable at first but at around the 4 hour point (6 hour game) bosses are introduced and then ran into the ground.
-Difficulty needs polishing. The default setting is more than do-able, but if I could go back I would have went with something easier. That way I could focus more on using powers and not have to worry about some stray explosion wiping me out.
-The last couple weapons are energy-based. They cover the enemy in blue-white flames which kinda makes it hard to tell that you've killed them. It's just not as satisfying when you can't see their arms fly off, their head pop like a meat balloon, and so on.
-General nitpicky stuff that an extra month in QA could have fixed.

All in all Inversion is good dumb entertainment. It's basically Timeshift influenced by Gears of War. Give it a go if you can find it on the cheap.

reviewText: Inversion is a cover-based first-person shooter from Saber studios, creator of 2007’s Timeshift. Knowing this you can expect a decent shooter.The story sees you play as cop Davis Russell, who along with his partner Leo Deglado, is in the midst of an alien invasion and looking to find Davis’ daughter. Set in the near future, an unknown army of evil enemies called the Lutadores have invaded the Earth and as Davis you struggle to battle this enemy through a rubble-strewn world where Gravity is not always as simple as being up and down.The character design and overall look and feel of the game is pretty good. The enemy have been designed to have a humanoid looking appearance but the language they speak indicates they are not a local enemy and could be from another planet.  Amongst this enemy you have your standard grunts and varying classes of enemy, including bosses.The difficulty of the game is something that really needs to be addressed before I talk more about the game. From the off, Inversion has 3 difficult settings, Low Gravity (easy), Normal Gravity (normal) and High Gravity (hard). If you are tough enough to complete the High Gravity setting you will unlock Black Hole gravity, however this does not have any achievements or trophies attributed to completing it.While the difficulty varies throughout the game, the levels are very linear, as you are guided from A to B of each checkpoint. There are no collectibles and no real exploration needed and this is a bit disappointing for a current gen game when compared to other shooters on the market.As you travel through each level you are accompanied by Leo. Players have the option to buddy up and use Leo as a multiplayer co-op experience, which is highly recommended, because the AI on this game is awful.The Unique selling point of the gravity shift has both a positive and negative impact on the game. There are sections of the game where you encounter gravity shifts that turn the environment upside down or on its side. This sounds like a novel addition to an FPS, but it does little to change the gaming experience, because you are doing the exact same thing you were doing a minute ago on the ground.The positives to the single player campaign though, and the most notable, is the zero gravity segments where gravity has been lost and you float through the environment using cars and rocks that have been left hanging in the air as cover against the enemy.You are able to reverse gravity and send enemies to their knees, which is great, but again does not offer very much. The other option that this low gravity ability has, is that it gives you a shield. Again, this can be very handy in those parts of the game that Saber have decided to make extremely difficult for no reason.With the solo campaign all covered, it would be remiss if I didn’t talk about the multiplayer aspect of this game. The matchmaking menu and options are great, with a huge amount of variety that players would expect to see in an FPS multiplayer, such as capture the flag, death match, team death match.It is a shame that with the wide variety and huge amount of challenges to complete in multiplayer, such as weapon and match type challenges that the matchmaking system was awful in allocating me a party.In summary, Inversion is a pretty good shooter that is worth being looked at by any fan of the genre. It is an enjoyable playthrough but not something that screams for a repeat performance.

reviewText:
So what's there to say about Inversion? A lackluster story and generic gameplay hidden behind semi-high production values. From the boring enemies that constantly remind me of God Hand but are nowhere near as interesting, to gameplay that promises to do so much and delivers so little it becomes more of a chore than a fun coop experience.

Some things it promises are destructable environments and controlling gravity. Well, most of the environment that gets destroyed is YOUR cover by enemies, not the other way around. As for the gravity powers, there's nothing very spectacular about it. It's a mix of Half Life and Psi Ops: Mindgate Conspiracy. Now this game is touted as a coop one. How does that hold up?

There are a lot of action sequences and using your powers to help each other or provide cover fire is important, but it's all marred by the soft relationship context moments where you have to 'bro' boost over a ledge or 'bro' hold a garage-ish door open so that the other guy can go through. It ends up becoming an awkward moment that really does nothing to help you feel like you're really working together to accomplish something. Instead of smart puzzles, you just get 'bro'ments.

By the end of the game, you will feel like there should and could have been so much more. It's sad because it could have been a great arcade experience, but focuses too much on its unpolished story and clunky gameplay moments to carry it across when those are its weakest points. The result is something that makes you want to finish but never provides any incentive to return. A decent 1 time play, but wait until it's super cheap before purchasing.

reviewText:
Inversion had a lot of potential. But its mediocre story and repetitive gameplay made it a forgettable ride for me. I played it with a friend and we laughed several times how silly the story was.

Also, while this is a cover-based shooter the game can easily have you defeated for being too long behind a cover. Enemies can simply hit you and you do not really have the best tactics to defeat your foes. There is a lot of trial-and-error here that makes the gameplay very irritating.

There are some really good ideas such as the gravity gun that lets you levitate objects. This should be used in several boss battles instead of the good old pull-the-trigger-until-it-dies method.

Inversion is not a bad game. It has potential but could have been given more polish. At this point it is mediocre at best and I do not really recommend it.

reviewText:
For the three-quarters of the game, Inversion comes off as a poorly-done rip-off of Gears of War. From its story, setting and characters, to it's pop-n-shoot gameplay, you will be constantly reminded of Epic's opus in grey-and-brown. It's only in the very last 10% of the game that Inversion finally starts to develop a personality of its own.

But for all that they blatantly stole so much from Gears, the developers failed to take the one thing that really mattered; interesting gameplay. And let's face it; Gears of War barely qualifies as interesting itself, so you know Inversion has to be  scraping the barrel if they can't even match the pedantic gameplay of Gears. The game has horrible controls (not that surprising in a port but disappointing nonetheless).  Its enemies and levels are hardly notable and its gunplay is bog-standard. The hook to Inversion is its ability to play around with the gravitational field, but nothing Inversion does is new or memorable. And, oh god is this game in love with its cut-scenes; it seems almost every action you take triggers a scripted - and uninterruptible -  animation.

On the plus side, there's some nice destructibility of the environments and the graphics are passable, especially consider it is a multi-platform title. But its reliance on cliched gameplay and shoddy technical aspects result in a poorly-designed, uninteresting mess of a game

A Video Game with a TV SERIES Asthetic.

Typically, when Game developers want to get into the game with a compelling story, they borrow a tried and true gameplay system in order to tell the story. Enter the game with the right mindframe, and you will LOVE IT.

60 FPS makes the difference.

I played the game on the xbox, and dealt with its flaws, ALL the time wishing it was smoother and Blah blah, but I just couldnt finish it, so it sits in a box. That said, I purchased it here on steam, and I love it. the graphics are awesome, and its smoothness adds to the gameplay, and the story and details drive the experience home.

I HAVE DISTINCT ISSUES WITH THE GAME. Serious misssteps.

-Online only co-op and versus
-no split screen (co op or versus)
-no bots to play against to practice (in case the servers are off and you would be stuck with half a game)

But as a Singleplayer romp, its a great game.

Inversion is the kind of game that had plenty of great Ideas, but because of its gears of war mechanics, the gravity sections which could have been awesome, seem like gimmicks (for the story), which makes it a regular Third person affair.

If you like shooters, and love razor sharp 60 fps graphics, with a TV series style storyline (which you will try to follow to the end, which I havent beaten it yet, but I savor every bit of good TV dialogue, and good TV acting) you will enjoy it a lot.

4 GB download, an it serves its purpose. I hope people buy it. but dont buy it hoping for multiplayer. this would only be good for that if you had a bunch of friends. but then again, other games do it better. they should have just added split screen, because not everyone would ever play this at the same time.

All in all, the game is well built, well designed, and the COD of GOW. LMAO. OMFG.

Scratch that last part, its just a good game, you will not be disappointed. definitely a sunday/rainy day game.

reviewText:
Set in, what I gather is an alternate world not unlike that of Judge Dredd (if you're not familiar with it, try looking for the movie with Silver Stallone), where the world is desolate and you live in a safe haven, a vibrant city in the middle.

Without spoiling too much, you are a police officer with a wife and daughter, just on your way home when the city is attacked by bandits (I gather). After some introductionary scenes explaining and training your ability with the basic controls while the storyline evolves you and your partner are captured, after which the game crashes for not apparent reason whatsoever (if the devs read this, that actually happened after the destruction of the first Unknown Robot, but I won't go into too much detail here about that)...

Anywho, what really gets this game going is the technology that enables you to shift gravity in objects you shoot at, or even yourself, allowing you to throw objects and enemies, pin them to the ground, walk on walls and ceilings, you name it. Combine that with a storyline that reminded me of Max Payne (for very apparent reasons if you have played both that game and this) and you really have something going.

The graphics look stunning closeby, but some objects did feel they were off, and some of the motion, especially on vehicles, looked really simple and something you'd expect to see in games 10 to 20 years ago... But then a building collapses in the distance with realistic smoke and debris flying everywhere, and then the building you're in does exactly the same and you forget all about that car or bus in the cut-scene.

I really don't like 3rd person shooters that much, but this one did get me captivated. I'll have another go at it later and hope the crash thing is just once in a while. The game auto-saves (more checkpoint based actually I think) so... This one is definately a keeper. Not sure what's with the multi-player, but I'm not much of a multi-player anyways.

reviewText:
I rarely post reviews of games because I just don't feel like it would contribute much to the already strong number of reviews on games.  Actually, I don't think I have done any.

For this game, I will make an exception.  While the game does have an interesting story, the voice acting and script is pretty horrible.  In addition, you don't really even like the characters.  The other promising part is the interesting concept of rotating gravity.  Unfortunately, all it provides is a promise... that it doesn't keep.

So much for the positives.  The action is completely repetitive, especially when it comes down to the boss fights.  Most of the game is casual, but then you come to boss fights later in the game where the difficulty skyrockets to levels that don't even make sense.  It would be different if the difficulty was due to requiring skill, but instead if you basically just hvae to figure out which stupid strategy is going to be required.  Is it going to be spamming lava balls?  Is it going to be running like a decapitated chicken to keep distance?  Is it reviving your somehow previously useful teammate constantly?  Either way, it is more an annoyance than some accomplishment.

Holy crap I almost forgot the cutscenes!  I have never seen so many of them in a game... ever.  And it isn't just to give the story, it is just to show you repeating the same teamwork to get over a wall sometimes.  I would say that over half the actually game was watching cutscense, with some just 30 seconds apart.  Some game designers have come up with ways to focus your attention on action/story without pulling you out of the game to watch a movie.  This game apparently wants you to watch their movie while occasionally participating in moronic boss battles and repetitive enemies.

This game is a rip off of Gears of War for the cover, HL2 for the gravity gun, and SATs for repetitive misery.  Can you find some enjoyable moments?  Yes.  Will you spend most of your time cursing the crappy controls, cover mechanics, inconsistant difficulty and insane amount of cutscenes?  Yuuuuuuup

reviewText:
Gravity is the most prevelent force in the universe; but if it could be harnest as a weapon, you'd have a significant advantage on the battlefield. This game takes that very concept and introduces it in a sort of Alien invasion setting. The story is told in a very cinematic way, which gets in the way of the gameplay. Many of the scenarios don't feel all that unique to most Trench-Style third-person adventures.It's almost as if a great deal of focus went into the Multiplayer vs the Main Story, which hurts the game's appeal, since it isn't available for MP or Co-op anymore. The lack of online Co-op forces you to rely on the Ai to not die(In which you will be given an opportunity to pick them up when downed). This can make the more difficult encounters more annoying, but not so much that it's a big issue.

The game's true faults start to arise when cutscenes clutter up the gameplay. It feels almost as if you never get a full experience until you've seen 8 or 9 cutscenes. The Linear nature of this game can be kind of limiting as well; but they did hide secret ammo stashes about the areas. Sometimes you'll get lucky and grab a really great weapon from one of these stashes that will make the limitations less apparent. Bosses are another thing handled pretty decently in this game, as they're not too difficult to send more casual players away; but offer enough challenge to put up a decent fight for anyone willing to select a higher difficulty. The Ai partner that you're forced to use now isn't too bad at holding his own; However there were segments when he would disapear. I theorized that he may have been stuck behind a game barrier during these sections.

After reaching a little over the half way mark, the game's true issues start to become more of an overcumberence. The Lack of an efficient partner makes some sections more RNG based; so you're either going to have a partner capable of having your back, or you wont. The other major fault is the lack of variety in enemies, as boss fights are repeated in the later sections, and very little is done to differentiate the experience. The Gravity mechanic becomes less useful in combat; because the enemies take much more to kill than the powers you have available to you. Often you're made to take on swarms of enemies that can't be brought down easily. It also serves to note that this game will crash at random; but it's negligible since the game saves often. You wont find yourself forced to redo sections if it crashes.

Upon reaching the bitter end of the game, it ramps up the difficulty once more; but the game cleverly forces you to attune yourself to using the gravity weapons, as ammo can easily run out. Ammo that once littered the area is difficult to stockpile, as well as some sections making you drop your secondary weapon if you happened to die before the next checkpoint. The repeated encounters with bosses is drummed up to a staggering bore at this point; but the variety is shaken up a bit. Combat becomes fierce and tactical as you progress through the final sections of the game; however the issues aparent with all of these Trench-Shooters start to become apparent. Not having a life bar often forces you to cowar in fear of the unkown amount of damage an enemy can inflict. It became frustrating not knowing whether I could weather a barrage of bullets,energy blast, fire, debris used as projectiles, or remain behind a safe barricade until I could pop my head momentarily to shoot.  I find these games rather enjoyable for the fast paced action (so I die alot.) If you've enjoyed this game, and are looking for something as fun as this, I can reccomend Binary Domain"
